Smith, Arthur Cornick
Shellbrook.

To Sask. - May, 1893

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire which will be answered by all individuals who have lived in Western Canada. Some of the questions here will not apply to everyone; others may prove impossible for you to answer. You should therefore fill out only those questions which you can answer accurately or completely. The questionnaire is intended for those who have lived in Western Canada before 1924, and may be answered by anyone who has lived there for more than one year. If more than one person lives in the same house, they should write their answers separately.

Other Questions:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire

Western Canada and the Prairies is still a new country, and many things are still being discovered. We would like to hear from you about your experiences in Western Canada. Please complete the questionnaire and return it to us.

Preservation:

All questionnaires will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our office at the University of Saskatchewan. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Board,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
Smith, Arthur Comick
Shellbrook.

To Sask., May, 1893

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES
No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire which will cover all aspects of pioneer life in Saskatchewan. However, we have prepared this questionnaire to provide a basis for gathering information about pioneer experiences.

This questionnaire is intended for those who have lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has lived there. If you are unable to answer any question, please leave it blank.

If you have any additional questions, please feel free to ask them.

Thank you for your cooperation.

Saskatchewan Archives Board

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: Arthur Cornick Smith
2. Your address: Shellbrook, Sask.
3. Date: April 7th, 1953
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): London, England
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Samuel Thomas Florist
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): 23rd of May, 1893
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: 27th of June, 1885 to Brandon, Manitoba; 9 years old, brought out to Canada from England by parents; 19 years old, Shellbrook, Sask.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you may say it was a small child.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West? To get a homestead to farm.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) Through other people at Brandon.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

NO. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: Arthur Cornick Smith
2. Your address: Shellbrook, Sask.
3. Date: April 7th, 1953
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) London, England
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Daniel Thomas Florist
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) 13th of May, 1893
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. 27th of June, 1885 to Chester, Manitoba - I was 11 years old. Brought out to Canada from England by my parents - and direct, Blackfoot, Alberta
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or if you may use "I was a small child")
9. What were your reasons for coming West? To get a homestead & farm
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) Through other people at home
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Eastern Canada? They thought I was going to be a great success.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)? I traveled with a group of friends.

13. How far did you travel from your home in Canada? We traveled about 500 miles.

14. What transportation did you use? We used a train.

15. What was your first job when you arrived in Eastern Canada? My first job was working at a factory.

16. What was your second job? My second job was working at a construction site.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Eastern Canada. I have lived in Toronto, Ontario, and Montreal, Quebec.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Eastern Canada? I worked as a laborer.

19. How long have you been employed at your current job? I have been employed here for 5 years.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home? I am alone... The world only a dear field in England, I wrote to her every week for a long time.

20. If you got married, give the name of the husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage. I married Miss Smith on December 25th, 1948.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? Yes, my brother came too.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came East tell when they came.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record? Growing up in the prairies was thrilling. Our family had plenty of work to do building a house and plenty of hay for our own cattle after years of hard work.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? By what means of travel?

Any traveling we done was with the train. We built a school house in 1895. We had to travel several miles to reach it.
13. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home? I was alone in England.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage. I married John Smith on June 15th, 1948.

21. Did anyone also come to Saba because of your recommendation? Yes, my family came.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came first, tell when they came and where they settled. We arrived in January 1948.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount? We had plenty of work to do for building a house and planting a garden for hay for our own use. We also had lots of game animals which we didn't have at home. They were very useful.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.? How often? By what means of travel?

Any traveling we done was with the train. We built a school here in 1895. We had hard times in it. It still has a school coming in.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What makes more sense?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? (Provide address)

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new terms, improved roads, better means of travel, etc.)

29. How often did you shop in the early days? When did you have to?

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? Our date

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? Then did you make this decision? I came to make my home here so I had no other choice.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1942? What reasons did they have for moving? To show till railway came. There in lots of good land.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "wired" to have or do something in the district mention it here, giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, building, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post offices, villages, railroad stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person expressing place-name (2) origin and meaning of name (3) date of its adoption. The Shell River is where the town got its name.
31. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1942? What reasons did they have for moving? To show till railway came. There is lots of good land here.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return after 1940?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "pioneer" to have or do something in the district mention it here stating date, wherever possible. (Such as the first automobile, building, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School Districts, Post Offices, villages, railroad stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person, (2) origin and meaning of the name, (3) date of its adoption. (4) any changes in names since the first name was given. Date and reason for change. Give facts of each name as above in (1), (2), (3).

The Shell River is where the town got its name.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:
Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences (personal)?
Placentville school was the name of the first school.

Would you or the person who owns them either:
(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?
(Indicate your preferences, if any)

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?
The railway, the new road, etc.
